questions.definition: Anything that has mass and takes up space.
The smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.
Two or more atoms bonded together.
A state of matter with a definite shape and volume.
A state of matter with a definite volume but no definite shape, taking the shape of its container.
A state of matter with no definite shape or volume, expanding to fill any container.
A change that affects the form of a substance but does not change its identity. Example: Ice melting into water.
A change that creates a new substance with different properties. Example: Burning wood produces ash and smoke.
The process of a liquid turning into a gas.
The process of a gas turning into a liquid. Example: Water droplets forming on a cold glass.
The process of a solid turning into a liquid.
The process of a liquid turning into a solid.
The amount of mass in a given volume of a substance.
The amount of space an object or substance occupies.
The amount of matter in an object, typically measured in grams or kilograms.
The ability of a substance to dissolve in a liquid.
A mixture where one substance is evenly distributed in another. Example: Salt dissolved in water.
The substance in which another substance is dissolved. Example: Water is a common solvent.
The substance that is dissolved in a solution. Example: Sugar is a solute in tea.
The temperature at which a liquid turns into a gas.
The temperature at which a solid turns into a liquid.
The physical form of a substance, such as solid, liquid, or gas.
A material that allows heat or electricity to flow easily. Example: Metals are good conductors.
A material that resists the flow of heat or electricity. Example: Rubber is a good insulator.
A chart of all known elements arranged by their properties.
